questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman, presented in labour room at 31st week of gestation, with evidence of fetal distress. The caesarian section was performed and a male baby was delivered. At birth, the baby presented with tachypnoea, expiratory grunting, retraction of ribs & sternum and cyanosis. X ray chest shows prominence of bronchial air shadows and a generalized opacity (ground glass appearance). Which of the following biomolecules are found to be deficient in baby?
questions.solution:
Topic: Lipid chemistry

Option A: Above characteristic clinical features at birth, and the radiological findings suggest a diagnosis of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

The underlying lesion in this disorder is deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, dipalmitoyl lecithin (lecithin also known as phosphatidyl choline) that prevents the collapse of alveoli.

It is after the 30th week of gestation that the fetus starts producing substantial amounts of dipalmitoyl lecithin and the optimum quantity required to prevent the collapse is reached at term.

In premature infants, sufficient levels of dipalmitoyl lecithin are not reached and at the time of birth there is a relative deficiency of the surfactant.

This results in lack of adequate alveolar expansion. Alveolar collapse and ventilation-perfusion abnormalities are the natural con sequences, which in turn cause respiratory distress.

Maturity of fetal lungs can be predicted in ante natal period by measuring the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio in the amniotic fluid.

The ratio begins to show a sharp increase at the 31st or 32nd week of gestation because of enhanced fetal production of dipalmitoyl lecithin. Soon it reaches to about 2.0.

Thus, a ratio of 2.0 or above in the amniotic fluid specimen is characteristic of the term infants. It indicates pulmonary maturity.

However, these results are unreliable if amniotic fluid specimen is contaminated by blood or meconium.

The sphingomyelin exerts no significant detergent activity in the lungs. It is measured only as convenient reference point for lecithin.

Option B: Phosphatidylinositol is a precursor of second messengers.

Phosphoinositides may have 1, 2, or 3 phosphate groups attached to the inositol ring.

Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PiP2 ), for example, is cleaved into diacylglycerol and inositol trisphosphate upon stimulation by a suitable hormone agonist, and both of these act as internal signals or second messengers.

Phosphorylated phosphatidyl inositols (phosphoinositides) are minor components of cell membranes, but play an important part in cell signaling and membrane trafficking.

Option C: Cardiolipin is found in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function.

Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathologic conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy)

Option D: Sphingomyelins are found in the outer leaflet of the cell membrane lipid bilayer and are particularly abundant in specialized areas of the plasma membrane known as lipid rafts.

They are also found in large quantities in the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve fibers. They are believed to play a role in cell signalling and in apoptosis.

Sphingomyelins contain no glycerol, and on hydrolysis they yield a fatty acid, phosphoric acid, choline, and sphingosine.

The combination of sphingosine plus fatty acid is known as ceramide, a structure also found in the glycosphingolipids.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number. 200

questions.text: A 50-year old business executive male, presented with pain and swelling in great toe in morning. He has history of taking alcohol and intake of non veg food previous night. On blood investigation, his uric acid level is found to be 9 mg/dl (normal 3.5 to 7 mg/dl). This clinical condition is associated with defect in which of the following metabolism?
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology_ Purine metabolism

This clinical condition suggesting hyperuricemia and gout.

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disorder occurs due to hyperuricemia. Due to low solubility of uric acid in water, it will get deposited in synovial joint, leading to arthritis.

Uric acid is an end product of purine nucleotide degradation. At physiological pH, uric acid is mostly ionized and present in plasma as sodium urate.

Uric acid and urate are relatively insoluble molecules which readily precipitate out of aqueous solutions such as urine or synovial fluid.

Option B: End product of pyrimidine catabolism is highly water soluble, so over production of pyrimidine catabolites is rarely associated with clinical disease.

Defects in pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis can lead to orotic aciduria.

Option C: The end product of protein catabolism is urea. Any defect in protein catabolism can lead to increased or decreased urea level in blood. Urea cycle defects can lead to hyperammonemia.

Option D: A defect in phenyl alanine catabolism can lead to phenylketonuria.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 33, page number:334

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, presented with abdominal pain & jaundice. USG abdomen showing stone in biliary tract. Patient also has steatorrhea. Absorption of all of the following vitamins are affected in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
Topic: lipid metabolism_ digestion and absorption of lipid

Here patient has obstructive jaundice, which result in defective digestion or absorption of fat leads to excretion of fat in stool which is known as Steatorrhea (Word stear means fat).

Option A, B, C: All lipid-soluble vitamins (Vitamin A (Retinol, Retinal, Retinoic acid), Vitamin D, Vitamin E & Vitamin K) are hydrophobic compounds that can be absorbed efficiently only when there is normal fat absorption.

During defective fat absorption, absorption of fat soluble vitamins is impaired.

Option D: Vitamin B12, Folic acid, Thiamine etc are water soluble their absorption is not impaired in steatorrhea.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 44, Page number:527

choices.text: Mutation in MRP 2 (Multi drug resistant protein 2)
Complete absence of UDP glucuronosyltransferase activity
Partial absent of UDP glucuronosyltransferase activity

questions.text: A 1 month old baby presented with severe congenital jaundice with bilirubin level 24 mg/dl. Child also has accompanying brain damage. A baby immediately kept under phototherapy and given phenobarbitone. Phototherapy reduces plasma bilirubin levels somewhat, but phenobarbital has no beneficial effect. Which of the following biochemical defect is seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Topic: Heme catabolism

Option A: Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is the benign autosomal recessive disorder consists of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in childhood or during adult life.

The hyperbilirubinemia is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the protein involved in the secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile.

The multi-drug resistance protein 2 (MRP2; ABCC2) is an ATP-binding cassette transporter playing an important role in detoxification and chemoprotection by transporting a wide range of compounds, especially conjugates of lipophilic substances with glutathione, glucuronate and sulfate.

Option B: In Type I Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, the severe congenital jaundice (over 20 mg bilirubin per dL serum) and accompanying brain damage of type I CriglerNajjar syndrome reflect the complete absence of hepatic UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity.

Phototherapy reduces plasma bilirubin levels somewhat, but phenobarbital has no beneficial effect. The disease is often fatal within the first 15 months of life.

Option C: In type II Crigler-Najjar syndrome, some bilirubin UDPglucuronosyltransferase activity is retained. This condition thus is more benign than the type I syndrome.

Serum bilirubin tends not to exceed 20 mg/dL of serum, and patients respond to treatment with large doses of phenobarbital.

In Gilbert Syndrome about 30% of the bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity is retained in Gilbert syndrome, the condition is harmless.

Option D: Rh incompatibility is associated with hemolytic anemia.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 31, Page number:314

questions.text: Photosensitivity is absent in which type of porphyria
questions.solution:
Topic: Heme catabolism

Porphyrias that present with Neurovisceral symptoms are Acute Intermittent Porphyria and ALA Dehydratase deficient Porphyria.

Porphyrias that present with Cutaneous Photosensitivity are Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria, Porphyria Cutanea Tarda, Erythropoietic Porphyria, X linked Protoporphyria.

Porphyria that presents with neurovisceral Symptoms and Cutaneous Photosensitivity is Hereditary Coproporphyria, Variegate Porphyria.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number 328.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme requires copper for activation:
questions.solution:
Topic: Enzyme - Cofactor

Collagen fibers are further stabilized by the formation of covalent cross-links, both within and between the triple helical units.

These cross-links form through the action of lysyl oxidase, a copper-dependent enzyme that oxidatively deaminates the ε-amino groups of certain lysine and hydroxylysine residues, yielding reactive aldehydes.

Such aldehydes can form aldol condensation products with other lysine or hydroxylysine-derived aldehydes or form Schiff bases with the ε-amino groups of unoxidized lysines or hydroxylysines.

These reactions, after further chemical rearrangements, result in the stable covalent cross-links that are important for the tensile strength of the fibers.

Now some Cofactor role of Copper

  • Amine oxidases
  • Ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin) (Iron metabolism, Copper Transport)
  • Cytochrome-c oxidase (in Complex IV of Electron Transport Chain)
  • Superoxide dismutase (Free Radical Scavenging enzyme)
  • Tyrosinase (Melanin Synthesis)
  • Component of ferroportin (Iron Metabolism)
  • Lysyl Oxidase (Cross linking in Collagen)

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number 628.

questions.text: Which of the following substance binds to CoA and condenses oxaloacetate to inhibit the TCA cycle:
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate - Carbohydrate metabolism

The poison fluoroacetate is found in some of plants,and their consumption can be fatal to grazing animals

  • Some fluorinated compounds used as anticancer agents and industrial chemicals (including pesticides) are metabolized to fluoroacetate
  • It is toxic because fluoroacetyl-CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number :161-167.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules will have structural homology with plasminogen and elevation of which result in premature coronal artery disease?
questions.solution:
Topic: lipid metabolism

Option A: Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (type I) leads to hypertriacylglycerolemia due to deficiency of LPL, abnormal LPL, or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL.

Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL. Low levels of LDL and HDL. No increased risk of coronary disease.

Option B: Familial hyperalphalipoproteinemia leads to increased concentrations of HDL. A rare condition apparently beneficial to health and longevity.

Option C: Familial lipoprotein(a) leads to excess Lp(a) consists of 1 mol of LDL attached to 1 mol of apo(a). Apo(a) shows structural homologies to plasminogen.

Premature coronary heart disease due to atherosclerosis, plus thrombosis due to inhibition of fibrinolysis.

Option D: Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa) occurs due to defective LDL receptors or mutation in ligand region of apo B-100.

Elevated LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia, resulting in atherosclerosis and coronary disease.


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 26 Page number:258

questions.text: Molecules up to size 4 KD is identified by:
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology - Molecular Technique

Quadrupole mass spectrometers generally are used to determine the masses of molecules of 4000 DK or less, whereas time-of-light mass spectrometers are used to determine the large masses of complete proteins.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number 31, 32

questions.text: A number of diseases like a variety of myopathies, neurologic disorders, and some forms of diabetes mellitus have now been shown to be due to mutations of mtDNA. Such mitochondrial DNA:
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology

Option A & Option B: Mitochondrial DNA is small circular Double-stranded DNA

Option C: Mitochondrial DNA contains very few untranslated sequences.

Option D: Mitochondrial DNA has high mutation rate.

Specific feature of Human mitochondrial DNA

  • Contains 2 to 10 copies of a small circular Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecule
  • Composed of heavy (H) and light (L) chains or strands
  • Contains 16,569 bp (~16 kbp)
  • Makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA
  • The majority of the polypeptides in mitochondria (about 54 out of 67) are encoded by nuclear genes, but some are coded by genes found in mitochondrial (mt) DNA.
  • Encodes 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (of a total of about 67)
    • Seven subunits of NADH dehydrogenase (complex I)
    • Cytochrome b of complex III
    • Three subunits of cytochrome oxidase (complex IV)
    • Two subunits of ATP synthase
  • Encodes large (16S) and small (12S) mt ribosomal RNAs
  • Encodes 22 mt tRNA molecules
  • Genetic code differs slightly from the standard code
    • UGA (standard stop codon) is read as Trp
    • AGA and AGG (standard codons for Arg) are read as stop codons
  • Contains very few untranslated sequences
  • High mutation rate (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA)
  • Comparisons of mtDNA sequences provide evidence about evolutionary origins of primates and other species
  • An important feature of human mitochondrial mtDNA is that it is transmitted by maternal nonmendelian inheritance, because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during zygote formation. Thus, in diseases resulting from mutations of mtDNA, an affected mother would theoretically pass the disease to all of her children, but only her daughters would transmit the trait.
  • However, in some cases, deletions in mtDNA occur during oogenesis and thus are not inherited from the mother.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 35 Page number:359

choices.text: Tight binding of pancreatic trypsin inhibitor
Cleavage protein on the carboxyl site of serine residues
Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site

questions.text: A common feature of all serine proteases is:
questions.solution:
Topic: Enzyme

While catalysis by aspartic proteases involves the direct hydrolytic attack of water on a peptide bond, catalysis by the serine protease chymotrypsin involves formation of a covalent acylenzyme intermediate.

A conserved seryl residue, serine 195, is activated via interactions with histidine 57 and aspartate 102.

While these three residues are far apart in primary structure, in the active site of the mature, folded protein they reside within bond-forming distance of one another.

Aligned in the order Asp 102-His 57-Ser 195, this trio forms a linked charge-relay network that acts as a "proton shuttle."

Binding of substrate initiates proton shifts that in effect transfer the hydroxyl proton of Ser 195 to Asp 102.

The enhanced nucleophilicity of the seryl oxygen facilitates its attack on the carbonyl carbon of the peptide bond of the substrate, forming a covalent acyl-enzyme intermediate.

The proton on Asp 102 then shuttles via His 57 to the amino group liberated when the peptide bond is cleaved.

The portion of the original peptide with a free amino group then leaves the active site and is replaced by a water molecule.

The charge-relay network now activates the water molecule by withdrawing a proton through His 57 to Asp 102.

The resulting hydroxide ion attacks the acylenzyme intermediate, and a reverse proton shuttle returns a proton to Ser 195, restoring its original state.

While modified during the process of catalysis, chymotrypsin emerges unchanged on completion of the reaction.

The proteases trypsin and elastase employ a similar catalytic mechanism, but the numbering of the residues in their Ser-His-Asp proton shuttles differ.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number :62-65

choices.text: Same enzyme classification with same number and name

questions.text: True about isoenzymes is:
questions.solution:
Topic: Enzyme - Iso enzyme

  • Isoenzymes catalyse the same reaction. For example, LDH1-5 all convert Pyruvate to lactate
  • They have different quaternary structure. For example, the subunits in LDH-1 is different from LDH-2
  • Tissue distribution of each isoform is different
  • Enzyme name and number can be different.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number :63

questions.text: A 60 year old male detected to have nonpolyposis colon cancer during colonoscopy. It was found to be hereditary in nature. Which of the following DNA repair mechanism can be defective here?
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular biology

Repair of damaged DNA is critical for maintaining genomic integrity and thereby preventing the propagation of mutations, either horizontally (somatic cells), or vertically (germ cells).

DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biologic assaults on a daily basis, hence efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential.

Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.

The mechanisms of DNA repair include

  1. Nucleotide excision repair (NER);
  2. Mismatch repair (MMR);
  3. Base excision repair (BER);
  4. Homologous recombination (HR); and n
  5. Nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) repair pathways

There are many diseases are associated with defective DNA repair mechanism:


So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number :63

questions.text: Number of ATP formed by oxidation of one molecule of palmitic acid (16 c):
questions.solution:
Topic: LIPID - Lipid Metabolism

Energetics of Beta Oxidation

The number of ATPs obtained depends on the number of Carbon atoms in the faty acid from Beta oxidation of Palmitic acid (C-16)

First calculate how many cycles of beta oxidation [(n/2)-1] where n = no of carbon atoms

  • In case of palmitic acid, 7 cycles of beta oxidation
  • From one cycle of beta oxidation
  • 1 FADH2 = 5 ATPs
  • 1 NADH = 2.5 ATPs
  • Total = 4 ATPs
  • From 7 cycles of beta oxidation
  • 7 × No of ATPs from 1 cycle
  • 7 × 4 = 28 ATPs

In case of Palmitic Acid (16/2) = 8 Acetyl CoA

  • From one Acetyl CoA by TCA Cycle 10 ATPs
  • From 8 Acetyl CoA
  • 8 × 10 = 80 ATPs
  • Total ATPs from Palmitic Acid = 28 + 80 = 108
  • 2 ATPs utilized for initial activation of Faty Acid
  • So net ATPs from Palmitic Acid = 108-2 = 106 ATPs.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:226

questions.text: A 43 year old obese female has been advised to increased intake of dietary fiber by nutritionist to reduce her weight. Which of the following is insoluble dietary fibre is?
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate chemistry

A non starch polysaccharides are not digested by human enzymes, and are the major component of dietary fiber.

Two types of dietary fibers:

Soluble fibers: Dissolved in water & form gel, Exaample: Pectins, gums, mucilages. Found in fruits & legumes

Insoluble fibers: Absorb water & swell up, Exaample: Cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin. Present in leafy vegetables & whole grains

Cellulose is a major dietary fiber. It is the chief constituent of plant cell walls. It is insoluble and consists of β-d-glucopyranose units linked by β1 → 4 bonds to form long, straight chains strengthened by cross-linking hydrogen bonds.

Mammals lack any enzyme that hydrolyzes the β1 → 4 bonds, and so cannot digest cellulose. Microorganisms in the gut of ruminants and other herbivores can hydrolyze the linkage and ferment the products to short-chain fatty acids as a major energy source.

There is some bacterial metabolism of cellulose in the human colon.

Option A: Lignin: Aromatic alcohol, Antioxidant action, found in fruits

Option B: Pectin occurs in fruits; it is a polymer of galacturonic acid linked α1 → 4, with some galactose an/or arabinose branches, and is partially methylated. Also considered as dietary fiber.

Option C: Mucilage consisting of polysaccharides containing hexose and pentose sugars and uronic acid, secreted by many plants.

Option D: Gum: Also known as Gum Arabic (GA) is a dissolvable dietary fiber, high molecular weight, low viscosity, and impartial tastes.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 15, Page number:147

questions.text: Zinc is a cofactor for:
questions.solution:
Topic: Enzyme - Cofactor

Metal ions constitute the most common type of prosthetic group.

The roughly one-third of all enzymes that contain tightly bound Fe, Co, Cu, Mg, Mn, and Zn are termed metalloenzymes.

Metal ions that participate in redox reactions generally are complexed to prosthetic groups such as heme or iron-sulfur clusters.

Metals also may facilitate the binding and orientation of substrates, the formation of covalent bonds with reaction intermediates (Co2+ in coenzyme B1), or by acting as Lewis acids or bases to render substrates more electrophilic (electron-poor) or nucleophilic (electron-rich), and hence more reactive.

Zinc is act as coenzymes in following enzymes

  • Carbonic Anhydrase
  • Carboxy Peptidase
  • Lactate Dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol Dehydrogenase
  • Alkaline Phosphatase

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:62

questions.text: A novel DNA editing system termed CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9) has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology - Molecular Technique

Option B: CRISPR-Cas9 system is directed by guide RNA and cleave specific site in between long chain of DNA, so it is RNA directed site specific endonuclease system.

The endonuclease cleaves or cuts the DNA from inside or in between the sequence while the exonuclease cut the DNA on the ends.

Option A: CRISPR-Cas9 system having endonuclease activity but not directed by DNA.

Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 system directed by RNA, but not having exonuclease activity.

Option D: CRISPR-Cas9 system neither directed by DNA nor having exonuclease activity.

CRISPR-Cas9

  • It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique
  • It was recognized by Emmanuelle Charpentierand Jennifer Doudna (awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020).

CRISPR: clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats

  • CRISPR found in genomes of prokaryotic organism (in bacterial and archaea).
  • It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.
  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophagesthat had previously infected the prokaryote.
  • Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.
  • So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages
  • CRISPR complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9: CRISPR associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA).
  • Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.
  • The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.
  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.
  • In medicine, it was used to experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (eg sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.
  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.
  • Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mammalian cells.
  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for potential specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition page number 435.

questions.text: Nucleoside is made up all of the following except
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology - Nucleotide Chemistry

Composition of Nucleoside

  • Nitrogenous base + Pentose Sugar
  • C1 of ribose or deoxyribose sugar to N¹ of Pyrimidine or N⁹ of Purine by β N Glycosidic linkage.

Composition of Nucleotides

  • Nucleoside + Phosphoryl groups
  • Usually phosphoryl group is attatched to 5’ hydroxyl group of pentose sugar by an ester bond.
  • Additional phosphoryl groups are attached by an Acid anhydride bond to form Nucleoside diphosphates and triphosphates

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:340

questions.text: Which of the following is not a features of genetic code?
questions.solution:
Topic: Molecular Biology - Nucleotide Chemistry

The characteristics of the genetic code are:

Option A: Unambiguous or Specificity: A particular codon always codes for same amino acid. It is not ambiguous.

Option B: Degeneracy: The genetic code is degenerate (sometimes called redundant).

Although each codon corresponds to a single amino acid, a given amino acid may have more than one triplet coding for it.

For example, arginine (Arg) is specified by six different codons Only Methionine (Met) and Tryptophan (Trp) have just one coding triplet.

Option C & D: Nonoverlapping and Non punctuated: The genetic code is nonoverlapping and commaless, meaning that the code is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases, taken three at a time without any punctuation between codons (commaless).

For example, AGCUGGAUACAU is read as AGC UGG AUA CAU.

Genetic code

Genetic information, stored in the chromosomes and transmitted to daughter cells through DNA replication.

But it is expressed through transcription to mRNA (messenger RNA), subsequent translation into proteins (polypeptide chains) with help of tRNA (transfer RNA).

During translation the language of the nucleotide sequence on the mRNA is translated into the language of an amino acid sequence.

Translation requires a genetic code, through which the information contained in the nucleic acid sequence is expressed to produce a specific sequence of amino acids.

Any alteration in the nucleic acid sequence may result in an incorrect amino acid being inserted into the polypeptide chain, potentially causing disease or even death of the organism.

Genetic code determines which amino acids are coded for by an mRNA.

Codons are presented in mRNA language of four nucleotides (adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C) and uracil (U)).

The four nucleotide bases are used to produce the three-base codons. So 64 different combinations of bases, taken three at a time (a triplet code).

The genetic code is virtually universal. An exception occurs in mitochondria, in which a few codons have meanings different than those shown in table.



Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Page number:395

choices.text: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple competitive inhibition
Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple non competitive inhibition
Graphical representation of a linear form of the Hill equation
Representation of sigmoid substrate saturation kinetics

questions.text: Identify the following graph:
questions.solution:
Topic: Enzyme

Option A: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple competitive inhibition is indicated by following graph


Option B: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple non competitive inhibition


Option C: A graphical representation of a linear form of the Hill equation is used to evaluate S₅₀, the substrate concentration that produces half-maximal velocity, and the degree of cooperativity n.


Option D: Representation of sigmoid substrate saturation kinetics is shown as S shape curve


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter:8 Page number:77

choices.text: Defect in SGLUT 1 in renal tubule
Increase excretion of excess glucose in urine due to bacterial infection
Decrease ability of glucose to reabsorb due to defect in SGLUT 2 in renal tubule
Increase absorbtion in intestine leads to increase secretion in urine

questions.text: A 33 year old female presented to the clinic with the complaint of frequent urination and burning during micturition. She revealed that she had been repeatedly suffering from these problems. Urine analysis revealed glycosuria. Fasting blood glucose and HbA1c were with in normal range. So what is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate - Carbohydrate metabolism

Urinary glucose with normal fasting blood glucose along with normal HbA1c indicates this is a case of renal glycosuria. Urinary tract infection is a possibility in this case and must be investigated with urine culture.

Renal glycosuria is caused due to decrease ability of kidney s to reabsorp filtered glucose in proximal tubule due to defect in sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLUT 2).

The high glucose in urine predisposes the individual to frequent urinary tract infection.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, Page number:597

questions.text: Glycogenin is a:
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate - Carbohydrate metabolism

  • Glycogenin is a protein
  • 37 K Da protein
  • Glycogenin catalyzes transfer of 7 glucosyl residues from UDPGlucose, in alpha 1 → 4 linkage
  • Glucosyl residues are added on specific tyrosine residues of Glycogenin
  • Glycogenin remains at the core of Glycogen granule.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:177

questions.text: A breast feed infant come with frequent vomiting and lose of weight. After many days he have develop jaundice, hepatomegaly, bilateral cataract. What is the possible diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate - Carbohydrate metabolism

Bilateral cataract is characteristics of Galactosemia.

Clinical manifestation of liver affected when milk is diet, is typical of galactosemia.

Bilateral cataract is not characteristics of HFI, Von Gierke's disease, Gaucher disease.

Juvenile DM no hepatomegaly and jaundice is seen.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, Page number:205.

choices.text: Represents primarily cholesterol that is being removed from peripheral cells
Binds to a receptor and cholesterol diffuses across the cell membrane
On accumulation in the cell it inhibits replenishment of LDL receptors
When enters a cell, suppresses activity of acyl- CoA: cholesterol acyl transferase ACAT

questions.text: Cholesterol present in LDL:
questions.solution:
Topic: LIPID - Lipopreotein Metabolism

  • Option A: LDL cholesterol is primarily from other lipoproteins where as HDL cholesterol is from peripheral organs.
  • Option B: Mechanism of uptake of LDL by LDL receptor
    • LDL receptors occur on the cell surface in pits that are coated on the cytosolic side of the cell membrane with a protein called clathrin.
    • The LDL receptor spans the membrane, the B-100 binding region being at the exposed amino terminal end.
    • After binding, LDL is taken up intact by endocytosis.
    • The apoprotein and cholesteryl ester are then hydrolyzed in the lysosomes, and cholesterol is translocated into the cell.
    • The receptors are recycled to the cell surface.
  • Option C: LDL is taken up intact, and not cholesterol alone diffuses across the membrane.

Cholesterol balance in tissues

This infux of cholesterol inhibits the transcription of the genes encoding

  • HMG-CoA synthase, HMG-CoA reductase, and other enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis
  • The LDL receptor itself, via the SREBP pathway

Thus coordinately suppresses cholesterol synthesis and uptake.

  • Option D: In addition, ACAT activity is stimulated, promoting cholesterol esterification.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:271

choices.text: 0 for those which are not readily hydrolysed in intestine
1 for those that are readily hydrolysed
Based on extent to which it reduces blood glucose level compared to equivalent amount of glucose

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Glycemic index of food?
questions.solution:
Topic: Carbohydrate - Diabetes mellitus

Option A: The glycemic index of a starchy food is a measure of its digestibility.

Option B & Option C: Glycemic index ranges from 1 (or 100%) for starches that are readily hydrolyzed in the small intestine to 0 for those that are not hydrolysed at all.

Option D: Glycemic index is based on the extent to which it raises the blood concentration of glucose compared with an equivalent amount of glucose or a reference food such as white bread or boiled rice.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 15, Page number 145.
